Charter

At the core of Judaica Digital Humanities (Judaica DH) at the Penn Libraries, we endeavor to incorporate these principles in all facets of our work.

Principle 1: Technology

  • We use digital technologies to augment and transform the ways in which to explore Jewish history and advance the field of Jewish Studies. By experimenting with platforms, tools, and methodologies, we deepen and broaden our understanding of Jewish history, texts, cultures, ideas, and experiences.

Principle 2: Jewish Identity

  • Our work aims to highlight and center Jewish lives: past, present, and future. By this we mean Jewish communities, Jewish intellectual production, and Jewish collections. We also play a central role in preserving Jewish memory, supporting the study of, access to, and re-use of cultural objects documenting the creativity of Jewish civilization.

Principle 3: Diaspora

  • We emphasize the connection between digital & diasporic. Describing the interaction of places, times, languages, identities, cultural formats, dominant and marginal narratives that characterize cultures and materials of the Jewish diaspora require a multidimensionality that digital humanities provides. As our projects bring together dispersed communities and materials, we think critically about how best to represent diverse facets of diasporic history, culture, and thought online.

Principle 4: Collaboration

  • Building on Penn’s commitment to integrate knowledge, we work with our collaborators to promote a public and participatory humanities. Bringing different disciplines and approaches together to lead scholarship in new directions, we believe Judaica DH at the Penn Libraries should sustain a collaborative network of trust, respect, and transparent communication. This collaborative spirit begins our foundational partnership between the Kislak Center for Special Collections, Rare Books and Manuscripts and the Center for Research Data and Digital Scholarship.

The Judaica DH principles were inspired by those of the Colored Conventions Project at the University of Delaware, the Scholars’ Lab at the University of Virginia, the Design Justice Network, Amanda Visconti’s mission statement for digital humanities at Purdue, and other charters & value statements listed in this spreadsheet. These principles also borrow from Jessica Marie Johnson’s “Diaspora”, Franceso Spagnolo’s Mapping Diasporas: Jewish Culture, Museums, and Digital Humanities”, Dov Winer’s “The role od digital/online resources in the Jewish Diaspora communities”, Michelle Chesner’s “JS/DH: An Introduction to Jewish Studies/Digital Humanities Resources” and the 2008 “Digital Humanities and African American/African Diaspora Studies” Conference at the University of Maryland, College Park.

Next Steps

With the the world’s first endowed position in Judaica digital humanities, our next phase allows us to take on a new set of projects at Penn Libraries.

In our next three years, Judaica DH activities will include modeling digital humanities research and publication best practices through collaborative internal projects; collaboration and outreach with the rest of Penn Judaica; and community events outside the university to ensure accessibility and usage of our materials. We will additionally improve our professionalization efforts as a program, by maintaining a well-documented Github organization; revamping our website to include project history and documentation; and sharing our scholarship through journal submissions, digital repositories, blogs, conference and workshop presentations. Our work will emphasize collaborative practice, value a public and inclusive humanities, and lead by modeling the possibilities of “#DHJewish” for the field of Jewish Studies.

Because we have limited staff time and resources, we’ll focus on a few specific new projects, maintaining specific elements of our legacy projects, and digital humanities networking with our collaborators on and off-campus, and outside the university

In our next phase, our new projects will include the following:

  • Against The Grain: The Farming Life In Jewish History: an atlas of Jewish farming communities from the 19th century to the present, encouraging the public to examine the power of agrarianisation in the Jewish world and the courage, tenacity, and resourcefulness of Jewish settlers (a collaboration with The Hebrew University of Jerusalem)
  • Caribbean Kehillot Documentation Project: exploring the Barbados Jewish community’s historical records, found locally and dispersed internationally in various related repositories (a collaboration with The HeritEdge Connection)
  • Ketubot VR Project: a virtual reality experience to explore the stages of a Jewish wedding ceremony
  • Jewish Sound at the Urban Periphery: a map of Philadelphia synagogues, past and present, tracing migration patterns and their impact on musical practice and identity

Work on our legacy projects include the following:

  • Scribes of the Cairo Geniza: As the host of this international collaboration, we will launch the remaining workflows of the project; encourage and support volunteer participation in the project; and maintain the project’s data for research use and output.
  • The Gershwind-Bennett Isaac Leeser Digital Repository - A Jesselson-Kaplan American Genizah Project: We plan to migrate the existing Leeser repository to an Omeka site, following the pattern of the Sabato Morais Digital Repository.
  • The Arnold and Deanne Kaplan Collection of Early American Judaica: We plan to make use of the use of this rich collection for online exhibitions around the changign character of Jewish life throughout the western hemisphere over four centuries.
  • Digital Second Edition of Judaica Americana: We plan to provide links from each monographic entry & serial entry (when possible) listed in the supplement to open access full-text versions of the items as found in HathiTrust, Internet Archive, Google Books, and elsewhere. We plan to highlight hosting PDF files of select Penn-specific entries for full-text searchability.

In terms of collaborations, we plan to achieve the following:

  • Uniting Penn Judaica, the Curator of Judaica Digital Humanities Herbert D. Katz Center for Advanced Judaic Studies and the Jewish Studies Program at Penn will work closely with the university community to facilitate the creation, use, and re-use of data in both instructional research environments.
  • Outside the university, we plan to strengthen our existing partnership with the Zooniverse, the e-Lijah Lab at the University of Haifa, and the Princeton Geniza Lab on Scribes of the Cairo Geniza to facilitate the use of crowdsourced data regarding Geniza fragments.
  • Outside the university, we plan to initiate our new projects with The HeritEdge Connection/The Hebrew University of Jerusalem/independent researchers.
  • We plan to form organizational partnerships outside universities to encourage a variety of communities to learn more about Judaica Digital Humanities and get involved in project initiatives in meaningful ways.
